pt: {sc}wit{/sc} {sc}humor{/sc} {sc}irony{/sc} {sc}sarcasm{/sc} {sc}satire{/sc} {sc}repartee{/sc} mean a mode of expression intended to arouse amusement. {sc}wit{/sc} suggests the power to evoke laughter by remarks showing verbal felicity or ingenuity and swift perception especially of the incongruous.
{sc}humor{/sc} implies an ability to perceive the ludicrous, the comical, and the absurd in human life and to express these usually without bitterness.
{sc}irony{/sc} applies to a manner of expression in which the intended meaning is the opposite of what is seemingly expressed.
{sc}sarcasm{/sc} applies to expression frequently in the form of irony that is intended to cut or wound.
{sc}satire{/sc} applies to writing that exposes or ridicules conduct, doctrines, or institutions either by direct criticism or more often through irony, parody, or caricature.
{sc}repartee{/sc} implies the power of answering quickly, pointedly, or wittily.

quotes.t: The great {qword}irony{/qword} of anthracite is that, tough as it is to light, once you get it lit it's nearly impossible to put out.

And the {qword}irony{/qword} is obvious: those who once had been the victims of separatism, who had sacrificed so dearly to overcome their being at the margins, would later create an ethos of their own separatism.

The great {qword}irony{/qword} of human intelligence is that the only species on Earth capable of reason, complex-problem solving, long-term planning and consciousness understands so little about the organ that makes it all possible—the brain.
